doc.field: Angkor Wat was built by King Suryavarman II in the early 12th century as his state temple and capital city <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Angkor Wat required considerable restoration in the 20th century, mainly the removal of accumulated earth and vegetation. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Angkor Wat - East Outer Wall Entrance II

Henri Mouhot, a French explorer once said : "Angkor Wat might take an honourable place beside our most beautiful buildings. It is grander than anything left to us by Greece or Rome, and presents a sad contrast to it's surroundings. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

The modern name, Angkor Wat, means "City Temple"; Angkor is another word for Nokor, which comes from the Sanskrit word Nagar. Wat is the Khmer form of the Pali word "Vatthu", meaning "temple grounds" <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Angkor Wat - Outer Wall Main Entrance

The first thing that strikes you when you arrive at Angkor Wat, is the immense moat and walll of 3.6 km around it. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

The monument was made out of enormous amounts of sandstone, as much as Khafre's pyramid in Egypt (over 5 million tons). <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Architecturally, the elements characteristic of the style include : the ogival, redented towers shaped like lotus buds; half-galleries to broaden passageways; axial galleries connecting enclosures; and the cruciform terraces which appear along the main axis of the temple. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>
city travel temple cambodia southeastasia buddhist angkorwat siemreap hindu unescoworldheritage templemountain archeologicalsite khmerarchitecture galleriedtemple

The stones, as smooth as polished marble, were laid without mortar with very tight joints that were sometimes hard to find. The blocks were held together by mortise and tenon joints in some cases, while in others they used dovetails and gravity. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>
city travel temple cambodia southeastasia buddhist angkorwat siemreap hindu unescoworldheritage templemountain archeologicalsite khmerarchitecture worldtrekker galleriedtemple

One of the first Western visitors to the temple was António da Madalena, a Portuguese monk who visited in 1586 and said that it "is of such extraordinary construction that it is not possible to describe it with a pen, particularly since it is like no other building in the world. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>
city travel temple cambodia southeastasia buddhist angkorwat siemreap hindu unescoworldheritage templemountain archeologicalsite khmerarchitecture galleriedtemple

The outer wall encloses a space of 820,000 square metres (203 acres), which (besides the proper temple) was originally occupied by the city and, to the north of the temple, the royal palace. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Like all secular buildings of Angkor, these were built of perishable materials rather than of stone, so nothing remains of them except the outlines of some of the streets. Most of the area is now covered by forest. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Angkor Wat - East Outer Wall Entrance I

The temple stands on a terrace raised higher than the city. It is made of three rectangular galleries rising to a central tower, each level higher than the last. Mannikka interprets these galleries as being dedicated to the king, Brahma, the moon, and Vishnu. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>
city travel temple cambodia southeastasia buddhist angkorwat siemreap hindu unescoworldheritage templemountain archeologicalsite khmerarchitecture galleriedtemple

It was designed to represent Mount Meru, home of the devas in Hindu mythology. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>
city travel temple cambodia southeastasia buddhist angkorwat siemreap hindu unescoworldheritage templemountain archeologicalsite khmerarchitecture galleriedtemple

Every culture has its legends of the origin of the species. The Hindu creation myth "Churning the Sea of Milk" is shown in the bas-relief panel at the East gallery of Angkor Wat. In Hindu mythology, 13 precious things including the elixir of immortality were lost in the churning of the cosmic sea. Finding them again required a joint dredging operation between gods and demons. Assisting in this endeavor was the giant serpent Vasuki, who offered himself as a rope to enable twirling of a "churning stick." The serpent was yanked back and forth in a giant tug-of-war that lasted for a thousand years. <a href"http:en.wikipedia.orgwikiAngkor_Wat" rel"nofollow">(Wikipedia)<a> <a href"http:whc.unesco.orgenlist668" rel"nofollow">(Unesco)<a> <a href"http:www.cameralenscompare.combadge2.aspx" rel"nofollow">☼<a>

Angkor Wat - Churning the Sea Of Milk
